It was sometimes called . ==History== In 708, Dewa-no kuni was separated from Echigo. In 712, Dewa and Mutsu Province were reorganizedTitsingh, Isaac. (1834). Annales des empereurs du japon, p. 64. Shiba Kaneyori received the Dewa Province as a fief from Ashikaga Takauji in 1335.Terry, Thomas Philip. (1914). Terry's Japanese Empire, p. 324. In the Meiji period, the provinces of Japan were converted into prefectures. The maps of Japan and Dewa Province were reformed in the 1870s.Nussbaum, Louis-Frédéric. (2005). "Provinces and prefectures" in Japan Encyclopedia, p. 780. ==Shrines and Temples== Ōmonoimi jinja was the chief Shinto shrine (ichinomiya) of Dewa.
